## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
Hey, I've been looking into Verus and I'm curious about the different types of currencies. What are the advantages of basket currencies over simple token currencies on Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
Basket currencies are more exciting than simple token currencies because they offer additional features that make them more valuable. Simple token currencies lack these features, making basket currencies more desirable. Would you like me to elaborate on what specific features make basket currencies more desirable?

**User:**
That helps clarify things. I also had a question about simple token currencies on Verus. Are they dynamic in terms of supply?

**AI Assistant:**
No, decentralized simple token currencies on Verus have a static supply. It's only the centralized version of these currencies where the owner of the rootID can mint tokens into existence, and anyone can burn them. Does that make sense?

**User:**
I've also been looking into the Verus-Ethereum Bridge. Is it a custodial bridge that holds users' tokens and currencies?

**AI Assistant:**
No, the Verus-Ethereum Bridge is a non-custodial bridge. This means that all tokens and currencies flowing over the bridge are never in anyone's custody, and are proven and verified by consensus rules. You always maintain control over your assets. Do you have any other questions about the bridge?

**User:**
That's really reassuring. One last question: Can only Verus currencies be exported to Ethereum as ERC-20 tokens?

**AI Assistant:**
No, any currency and token, on Verus or any other PBaaS-blockchain, can be exported to Ethereum as an ERC-20 token. Additionally, any already existing ERC-20 token can be mapped one-to-one as a Verus currency. So, there's a lot of flexibility when it comes to moving assets between Verus and Ethereum.
What are the advantages of basket currencies over simple token currencies on Verus?

Basket currencies are more exciting than simple token currencies because they offer additional features that make them more valuable. Simple token currencies lack these features, making basket currencies more desirable.

## Simple token currencies
Simple token currencies and are just currencies without any reserves. They are not as exciting as the basket currencies, yet still offer much value. With all the parameters that can be added, subIDs created and decentralized crowdfund mechanisms, these currencies can support a lot of use cases that are difficult to do with alternative protocols.The supply of this type of currency is static when it’s a decentralized version. When it’s a centralized version, the owner of the rootID can mint tokens into existence, and anyone can burn them.This option is also used to create currencies that are mapped to Ethereum ERC-20s. Which means you can send those ERC-20s over to Verus, or from Verus to the ERC-20. This is made possible with the non-custodial Verus-Ethereum Bridge. You can read more about it here.And of course, a simple token currency can be one of the reserves in a basket currency.## Ethereum ERC-20 
The Verus-Ethereum Bridge makes it possible for currencies and tokens to be send over to Ethereum, and back to Verus. It is a true non-custodial bridge. All tokens and currencies flowing over the bridge are never in anyone’s custody, and are proven and verified by consensus rules. [Everything on the Verus-Ethereum Bridge here.](/eth-bridge/)Any currency and token, on Verus or any other PBaaS-blockchain, can be exported to Ethereum as an ERC-20. They can then be used in the Ethereum ecosystem.Also, any already existing ERC-20 token can be mapped one-to-one as a Verus currency. Meaning any ERC-20 token can live on the Verus blockchain (or any other PBaaS-chain) and take advantage of all the L1 features.
